desc: prove that n^4+4^n is composite for all n>=2
solution:
\begin{soln}
    We divide the solution into two cases based on the parity
    of $n$.

  \begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{If $n$ is even:} Then $4\mid n^{4}$ and
      $4\mid 4^{n}$ which implies $4\mid n^{4}+4^{n}$ which
      makes it composite.
    \item \textbf{If $n$ is odd:} Then let $n=2k+1$ where
      $k\ge 1$ as $n\ge 3$.

      Then $n^{4}+4^{n}=n^{4}+4\cdot 2^{4k}$. Let $2^{k}=m$.
      \[
        n^{4}+4^{n}=n^{4}+4\cdot m^{4}=(n^{2}+2m^2-2nm)
        (n^2+2m^2+2nm)
      .\]
      
      To finish, note that,
      \[
        n^2+2m^2+2mn>n^2+2m^2-2mn=(n-m)^2+m^2\ge 4
      .\]
      Thus both the two numbers are $\ge 4$ which means that
      their product is composite.
  \end{itemize}
\end{soln}
